chunks.text: Well, a more sophisticated model is something  like a naive Bayes model that says, if you have a disease,  where's my cursor?  If you have a disease and you have  a bunch of manifestations that can be caused by the disease,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: we can make some simplifying assumptions  that say that you will only ever have one disease at a time,  which means that the values of that node D  form an exhaustive and mutually exclusive set of values.  And we can assume that the manifestations are

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: conditionally independent observables that depend only  on the disease that you have, but not on each other  or not on any other factors.  And if you make that assumption, then  you can apply good old Thomas Bayes' rule.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: This, by the way, is the Reverend Bayes.  Do you guys know his history?  So he was a nonconformist minister in England.  And he was not a mathematician, except he  was an amateur mathematician.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: But he decided that he wanted to prove to people  that God existed.  And so he developed Bayesian reasoning  in order to make this proof.  And so his argument was, well, suppose

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: you're completely in doubt.  So you have 50-50 odds that God exists.  And then you say, let's look at miracles.  And let's ask, what's the likelihood  of this miracle having occurred if God exists

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: versus if God doesn't exist?  And so by racking up a bunch of miracles,  you can convince people more and more  that God must exist, because otherwise all these miracles  couldn't have happened.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So he never published this in his lifetime.  But after his death, one of his colleagues  actually presented this as a paper  at the Royal Society in the UK.  And so Bayes became famous as the originator

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: of this notion of how to do probabilistic reasoning  about at least fairly simple situations,  like in his case, the existence or nonexistence of God,  or in our case, the cause of some disease,  the nature of some disease.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And so you can draw these trees.  And Bayes' rule is very simple.  I'm sure you've all seen it.  One thing that, again, makes contact with medicine  is that a lot of times, you're not just

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: interested in the impact of one observable on your probability  distribution, but you're interested in the impact  of a sequence of observations.  And so one thing you can do is you can say, well,  here is my general population.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So let's say disease 2 has 37% prevalence,  and disease 1 has 12%, et cetera.  And now I make some observation.  I apply Bayes' rule, and I revise my probability  distribution.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So this is the equivalent of finding a smaller  population of patients who have all had whatever  answer I got for symptom 1.  And then I just keep doing that.  And so this is the sequential application of Bayes' rule.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And of course, it does depend on the conditional independence  of all these symptoms.  But in medicine, people don't like to do math, even  arithmetic, much.  And they prefer doing addition rather than multiplication,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: because it's easier.  And so what they've done is they said, well,  instead of representing all this data  in a probabilistic framework, let's represent it as odds.  And if you represent it as odds,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: then the odds of some disease given a bunch of symptoms,  given the independence assumption,  is just the prior odds of the disease  times the conditional odds, the likelihood ratio,  of each of the symptoms that you've observed.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So you just get to multiply these together.  And then because they like adding more than multiplying,  they said, let's take the log of both sides.  And then you can just add them.  And so if you remember when I was talking about medical data,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: there are things like the Glasgow Coma score,  or the Apache score, or various measures of how badly or well  a patient is doing that often involve adding up  numbers corresponding to different conditions  that they have.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And what they're doing is exactly this.  They're applying sequentially Bayes' rule  with these independence assumptions  in the form of logs rather than multiplications, log odds.  And that's how they're doing it.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: OK.  Very quickly, somebody in a previous lecture  was wondering about receiver operator characteristic curves.  And I just wanted to give you a little bit of insight  on those.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So if you do a test on two populations of patients,  the red ones are sick patients.  The blue ones are not sick patients.  You do some test.  What you expect is that the result of that test

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: will be some continuous number.  And it'll be distributed something  like the blue distribution for the well patients  and something like the red distribution  for the ill patients.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And typically, we choose some threshold.  And we say, well, if you choose this  to be the threshold between a prediction of sick or well,  then what you're going to get is that the part  of the blue distribution that lies to the right

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: is the false positives.  And the part of the red distribution  that lies to the left is the false negatives.  And often, people will choose the lowest point  at which these two curves intersect as the threshold.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: But that, of course, isn't necessarily the case.  Now, if I give you a better test, one like this,  that's terrific because there's essentially  no overlap, very small false negative and false positive  rates.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And as I said, you can choose to put the threshold  in different places depending on how  you want to trade off sensitivity and specificity.  And we measure this by this receiver operator  characteristics curve, which has the general form

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: that if you get a curve like this,  that means that there's an exact trade-off for sensitivity  and specificity, which is the case if you're flipping coins.  So it's random.  And of course, if you manage to hit the top corner up there,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: that means that there would be no overlap whatsoever  between the two distributions.
